My favorite restaurant in Milano. 1* Michelin. Elegant lunch experience, smooth ambiance and music. Fantastic Napoletan ragu. Amazing creme caramele with castagne and matcha. Tried Schioppettino wine - loved it. Best focaccia so far.

Went for a birthday lunch, great food and service by the service staffs. Highly recommended if u dont want to spend so much for dinner because of Michelin star,lunch is not Michelin but it was fantastic too. They were so nice to even gave us the whole birthday choc cake free of charge! And the cake tasted amazing too!

Really special experience here with not just amazing dishes but served with creative flair at the table. Everything is presented impeccably down to the box for the snacks. And of course the dining room itself is beautiful.

Formal dining but the waiting staff were very friendly and polite. They were happy to let us take the little sweet treats away after which I wasn't sure would be the case.

Modern, chic, relaxed. The service was kind and very attentive, soft spoken and professional. The food was inventive but not tacky, classic with a contemporary perspective. The ingredients were very fine and the flavors were interesting.
Great lobster, delicious foie gras, tender cod, hearty but juicy pigeon. Interesting wine pairings with an entertaining local touch. An exceptional bread selection.

Sadler was a food experience. From the moment you want through the doors, you realize you are there to explore creative dishes that call you to be open. I never thought I would eat beets again, yet I did!

reviews.text:
The scent of ancient books...
Garibaldi's letter to Anita...

The food was great- so many options for seafood. We really enjoyed all the dishes down to dessert. the wine list was extensive and impressive. But I would generally rate this restaurant a 3.5 because the service was horrible. We’re well aware that we have our table for only 2 hours but each dish we had, we were practically rushed to eat. My companion was even still enjoying the sauce of the shrimp with the bread it was served with (as suggested by the other server) but the one who kept clearing our table kept standing by and hurriedly would remove our plates. This was so frustrating and caused such a negative experience for me. Trying this ONCE was enough but I can’t say it left a good impression for me to want to go back. Many other restaurants in Milan that would match great service for the price you’re paying for anyway.

Langosteria in Milan was incredible! The food was fresh, flavorful, and beautifully presented. Every dish we tried was absolutely delicious. The atmosphere was elegant but relaxed, and the service was top-notch. Honestly, it deserves a Michelin star  it’s that good. Highly recommended!

Returning to Langosteria after ten years, I was once again deeply impressed.
The service, hospitality, and quality of ingredients remain top-notch,
while the atmosphere has settled into an even more refined calm.
It may not be as bustling as before—perhaps a sign of the times—
but it’s still the finest seafood restaurant, with the finest ingredients.

Incredible upscale restaurant in Milan. Our friends who live here said it’s the best Milan has to offer. It was our first time, and we tried the tasting menu which was 7 courses and gave you a taste of everything. Would definitely recommend and look forward to coming back!

This restaurant offers a refined setting with a clear focus on high-quality seafood. It maintains a sophisticated yet understated atmosphere, suitable for both business dinners and special occasions.

The menu is centered around fresh fish and shellfish, with a mix of raw and cooked dishes. Execution is precise, and the quality of ingredients is evident throughout the meal. The wine list is extensive.

Service is discreet and professional, contributing to a smooth and well-managed dining experience. While the price point is on the higher end, it aligns with the standard of food and service provided.

All in all, I find it a solid choice for those seeking an elegant seafood-focused meal.

Service is discreet and professional, contributing to a smooth and well-managed dining experience. While the price point is on the higher end, it aligns with the standard of food and service provided.

All in all, I find it a solid choice for those seeking an elegant seafood-focused meal.

The Filarete Tower is the iconic central entrance of Milan’s Sforza Castle. Rebuilt in the early 1900s, it blends Gothic and Renaissance styles beautifully. A symbol of Milan’s rich history, it’s a must-see landmark in a truly stunning location.

This is the central entrance tower of Castello Sforzesco and one of its most recognizable landmarks. It was originally commissioned in 1452 by Duke Francesco Sforza and designed by Antonio Averlino, known as Filarete. The structure featured a two-tiered square base, a clock level, a watchtower, and a cylindrical turret crowned with a dome. In 1521, the tower was completely destroyed by an explosion in its internal munitions depot. Between 1891 and 1905, Luca Beltrami reconstructed the tower based on 16th-century drawings. The restored tower was dedicated to King Umberto I and completed in 1905. The clock on the second level was added during this reconstruction.

Great place to visit as it’s free, has lots of historical sites to see and a museum which wasn’t free but still, an amazing area with a park next to it, great for exploring and having a lazy day. Do we warned in the summer months it’s gets busy and is also very hot
Quite the place with an amazing history.  Must have been fascinating back in sforza day

An impressive and striking tower that front the Sforza Castle complex. Designed by the Renaissance architect Antonio Averlino, also known as Filarete, the tower features a unique cylindrical shape and is adorned with decorative elements, showcasing the artistic and architectural style of the period.

You can enter the grounds through this entrance and either pay to enjoy the museum, or just wander around the extensive grounds for free. There are lots of nice spots to sit and enjoy the surroundings.

Stayed at Hotel Spadari in Milan and had a lovely experience. The rooms are clean and comfortable—simple but well-kept. What really sets this place apart is the staff: absolutely wonderful, warm, and always happy to help. A special mention to Francesca, who looked after us so kindly during happy hour—her warmth and attentiveness were just what we needed after long, exhausting days exploring the city. The location is also perfect, right in the heart of Milan’s shopping district and close to all the main attractions. Highly recommend for anyone looking for a central and welcoming place to stay.

I stayed at this wonderful hotel for two days, and it's easy to see why it's rated #1 on TripAdvisor. The moment you walk in, you are welcomed. I asked for a couple of recommendations away from the crowds of people, and they do exist, just a few hundred meters away. Rooms are in a very warm and welcoming environment. Breakfast can be made to order and can't be missed. I was on my way to Lake Como and this was a great place to stop off for a few days. Subway stop is around the corner. Travelers, you won’t be disappointed here

The location is absolutely perfect, right in the city center, making it incredibly convenient for exploring the city's attractions.
The rooms are comfortable and impressively clean.
The staff  was extremely friendly and created a welcoming, home-like atmosphere throughout our stay.
The breakfast was excellent, offering a wide variety of delicious options. A unique and delightful feature was the daily aperitivo hour in the charming small lobby.
The complimentary soft drinks in the mini-bar were a thoughtful touch.
Overall, this hotel offers exceptional value with its central location, clean rooms, friendly service, and those extra touches that make your stay in Milan truly memorable. Highly recommended!

This hotel is situated in the central business district just 1 block from Duomo di Milano. The surrounding streets are bustling with the activity. Our room was very unique with a sitting area, separate bedroom with water closet down stairs and a full bathroom upstairs, which included a large bath tub and large rain fall shower. There's a view of an enter rooftop garden for this room; no city views in this room. This was okay for us, as our days were spent exploring the streets around the hotel and peaceful rest is what we were seeking in the evenings. The hotel staff was very friendly and helpful staff.

Fantastic hotel and fantastic service, reception and breakfast staff!!!
Many thanks.
Best regards from Poland

Day 2.name: Chiesa di San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore

reviews.text:
A local artisan, jeweler, sent us hear. Breathtaking views
Oils
Portraits.

Various artists from the 1500
Bringing the words of the Bible to life.                 The experience was solem and reflective.

Worth the walk.
Be blessed:
Not by idols
Not by tradition
Not by a religion
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
But
live for and Follow the Lord Jesus Christ

Hidden gem.
The most beautiful church in Milan in my opinion. It is highly recommended to visit it and enjoy the  beautiful artwork and hand made paintings on the wall and ceiling.

Absolutely must see. Hidden away gem.
One of only two churches in Milan where every corner in the monastery is covered in stunning hand paintings. Some great history behind the cut icons from when the church was used as a shelter for Napoleon army during the war. Must visit and spend some time to appreciate the stunning paintings.

Located at Corso Magenta, 15, 20123 Milan MI, Italy 🇮🇹.
This chapel is quite underrated because it doesn’t look as eye catching as the famous Milano Duomo. Once I walked inside though, I was struck by the sheer beauty of it. Everything in San Maurizio has colour, whether it’s paintings, mosaics or gold glitters everywhere. Nothing is uncovered by some form of colour including the pillars, ceilings and walls. The church is nicknamed the ‘Sistine Chapel’ of Milan.
The church is located at what used to be the most important convent for women in Milan. The construction of this church took about fifteen years and took place in the sixteenth century. The building was split into two parts – one for the nuns and one for the faithful – and it was not until the end of the eighteenth century that this strict barrier disappeared.
The church is not very big, but it’s definitely worth visiting. There’s no admission fee and the staff are friendly and welcoming. I am so glad I visited San Maurizio. Thumbs up!!! 👍👍👍

This place was FREE to enter?? That in and of itself is enough incentive to come and visit. More remarkable murals than some of the other places that I visited in Milan and those all cost money. Definitely glad we stumbled on this impressive piece of art!

Day 2.name: Duomo di Milano
Day 2.address: Milan Cathedral, P.za del Duomo, Milano

reviews.text:
Great place to visit, truly a home of Lord God. Great architecture. Better buy tickets o line but do a research where to buy since there are some scam websites. Also be aware that there are different tickets: for the terrace, for the Duomo itself, for the archeology to go down to basement and so on.

Prepare yourself: cannot bring tin cans, like coca cola or Pepsi, also food is not allowed here. There are certain look requirements, look those up on the Internet.

Visiting the Duomo di Milano was one of the most memorable experiences of my trip to Italy. Even before you step inside, the exterior takes your breath away. The sheer scale of the cathedral, combined with the intricate Gothic architecture and countless statues and spires, is simply awe-inspiring. It’s the kind of place that makes you stop in your tracks.

Inside, the atmosphere is just as powerful. The stained-glass windows are absolutely stunning, casting colorful light across the vast interior. The detail in every column, sculpture, and altar shows the centuries of craftsmanship and devotion that went into building this masterpiece. It’s both peaceful and overwhelming at the same time.

One of the highlights for me was taking the stairs up to the rooftop. It’s a bit of a climb, but totally worth it. Walking among the spires and seeing the city from above – with the Alps in the distance on a clear day – is an experience I won’t forget.

Whether you're religious or not, the Duomo is a place that speaks to you. It’s more than just a tourist attraction – it’s a symbol of Milan, history, and human creativity.

Don’t miss it if you’re in the city. Truly unforgettable.

The highlight for me was going up to the rooftop terrace. From there, you can admire not only the intricate details of the cathedral itself but also enjoy a panoramic view of Milan. It’s definitely worth the climb. Inside, the stained-glass windows are stunning and create a magical atmosphere with their vibrant colors.

Spectacular edifice with a great history.  Both the roof tour and the inside tour are worth doing.  Lots of stairs for the roof tour, but not too bad, as they are unidirectional — not need to get past people in the narrow spiral stone staircases.  There was a mass ongoing during our visit, which was beautiful.  Many great works of art and architecture.  A highlight of Milan.

Stepping up to the Duomo di Milano was an incredible experience, and it holds a special place in my heart because it was the very first place I ever visited as a solo traveller.

You see pictures of it, but they really don't do it justice. The sheer scale and intricate detail of the Gothic architecture are absolutely breathtaking. I remember just standing in the piazza for a good long while, just taking it all in—the spires, the statues, every little carving. It was an awe-inspiring moment that made me feel so small and, at the same time, so empowered to be out there on my own.

The best part, without a doubt, was climbing to the rooftop terraces. The views are out of this world! You get to walk right among the spires and statues, with a 360-degree panorama of Milan. I went just as the sun was starting to set, and watching the city turn to gold from up there was something I'll never forget. It was the perfect ending to my first day of solo travel, a moment of pure freedom and beauty.

Even the inside is stunning, with all the stained-glass windows and massive columns. But for me, it was that moment on the roof, surrounded by that incredible craftsmanship, that made it a truly unforgettable experience.

details.adr_address: P.za del Duomo, 20122 Milano MI, Italy

editorial_summary.overview: One of the largest cathedrals in the world, this iconic masterpiece took over 600 years to complete.

reviews.text: Such an incredible stay! You walk through the entrance and are transported to another time, a calm, luxurious respite in the middle of the city. The staff is so welcoming and attentive from check in to check out and every detail feels very intentional. The bed and linens might just be the most comfortable we’ve ever experienced—it was such a restorative sleep! We cannot wait to return!

The best part of visiting Milan is our hotel, thank you so much Grand hotel staff you made our trip extra memorable..
Everything about this hotel is perfect: Reception staff are so helpful and welcoming
Interior of the hotel feels like a historic museum,
Rooms and everything about the rooms(space, bathroom, hygiene, soap and shampoo quality..)
And we receive small gift every time we’re back after a long day out.

Location of the hotel is perfect as well, its few minutes walking to Duomo and shopping areas around there.

It’s worth every penny you pay🥰🥰

If you need to visit a really busy city like Milano, this hotel has quite the elegance. Super staff, peaceful energy even while being in the city center. Stayed in Verdi’s room. Pretty exciting, but very quiet.

We spent one day in and out of Milan, staying at the Grand Hotel et de Milan—and what an experience it was! From the warm welcome at the front desk to the attentive service in the bar area, everything exceeded our expectations. We had a spacious and comfortable double room and were consistently met by helpful staff who truly wanted to make a difference.

We will definitely be back!

Grand Hotel et de Milan is an Excellent Place.

Full of memories, art, music stories and international culture. Even a drink there, at the Gerry's bar, taste different; of neverending historical beauty!
Just Go and see .

Being there for the press presentation of George Simenon  appraisal exhibition was a splendid idea and location, ended with a rich buffet furnished with a lovely cocktails

Tremendous castle museum, well worth spending a morning or afternoon here. Packed full with art of every kind, from paintings to sculpture to furniture and other material culture items. Buildings themselves also of interest. Lockers in the basement to store bags, which are not allowed in the paid areas. Very good value. Could make more money by charging more and having a bigger gift shop.

Sforzesco Castle feels less like a tourist attraction and more like a time machine parked in the middle of Milan. I visited on a sunny afternoon, and walking through the massive gates felt like entering another world—one that echoes with the footsteps of dukes, soldiers, artists, and everyday Milanese.

The inner courtyards are stunning—grand but oddly peaceful, with locals sitting in the shade or reading a book on the benches like it’s just another Sunday. I spent a good hour just wandering around the outer walls and moat before even entering any of the museums.

Inside, it's a treasure trove. I wasn’t expecting to see Michelangelo’s last sculpture just sitting quietly in one of the rooms. That alone gave me chills. The museum layout is a bit old-school, but charmingly so, and the variety of art and artifacts—from Renaissance armor to Egyptian relics—is impressive.

I recommend going early or later in the day—it can get a bit crowded, especially near the main courtyards. Also, if you have time, grab a gelato and stroll through Parco Sempione behind the castle—it's the perfect way to end the visit.

Definitely one of the most memorable places I saw in Milan. Not just for the beauty, but for the soul it carries.

Taking a different direction in my strolls through Milan I came across this amazing looking castle in the city - obviously quite old. It is at the edge of a large park which itself was very interesting. Ie, you can find at the opposite side a Napoleon lll version of the arc de triumph. BTW, I was told that within the fortress there was some work by Michelangelo but it was closed the day I visited.

Very beautiful castle with lots of exhibitions on different topics. We spent hours there. At the end it was too much input.
Every first and third Tuesday of the month the entrance is free. Not sure if the whole day or after 2pm (read different information). We arrived at 2:30pm and it was definitely free. Closing time was 5:30pm.

Huge, beautiful castle, which mostly served as a palace for the royal Sforza family, in the center of Milan. It is a popular place to visit, so if you want to see art inside, you should probably buy tickets in advance  (I did). The museums inside contain a treasure trove of art, including the last sculpture of Michelangelo (The Rondanini Pieta), paintings of Mantegna, Titian, Tintoretto and others. The famous Sala delle Asse was closed, but you were still able to pick inside to see a very faded Leonardo painting on the ceiling. A separate ticket is required to walk on the castle wall and absorb a great view from the top. There is a park behind the castle where you can stroll for the rest of the day
